variant.question:
Complete the following statement:
The ____ is/are responsible for the issuance of special air-reports.

options.text: Pilots
Operator
Meteorological Watch Office
World Area Forecast Centres

variant.question: When air-ground data link is used, automated routine observations should be made (reports of air temperature, wind and turbulence). What is correct about aircraft not equipped with air-ground data link equipment?

options.text: They shall be exempt from making regular reports, unless specifically requested by ATC.
They are only required to make reports upon passing reporting points, not more than 30 minutes every time.
They are required to make regular reports, regardless of position.
They are only required to report once, immediately after being requested.

variant.question:
The aircraft, a pilot is flying, is not fitted with ACARS
 How can the pilot obtain routine weather reports (METARs) for specific airports?

options.text: Maintain listening watch on the VOLMET frequency.
Maintain listening watch on the AFIS frequency.
Enquire via voice on the frequency allocated to ATIS.
Request SIGMET on the international guard frequency.

variant.question: If you are requested to "Report flight conditions", what does that mean?

options.text: Indicate whether you are flying in IMC or in VMC.
Indicate weather conditions as wind, visibility, temperature.
Indicate whether you are flying IFR or VFR.
Indicate if visibility is sufficient for landing.

variant.question:
An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud
 The aircraft does not encounter hail
 Must this be reported and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
There is no requirement to report such a thunderstorm.
Yes, in the aircraft`s next routine meteorological report.
Yes, after landing.

variant.question: An aircraft has a maximum rate of climb of 1500ft/min, radar instructs the aircraft to climb at 2000ft/min. what is the pilots response.

options.text: Unable.
No.
Wilco.
Negative.

variant.question: While cruising level, severe turbulence affects the aircraft’s capability to maintain the height-keeping requirements for RVSM. How should the pilot inform ATC?

options.text: “Unable RVSM due to turbulence”
“Negative RVSM”
“Not RVSM any more due to turbulence”
“RVSM not approved due turbulence”

variant.question:
The route forecast included the chance of isolated thunderstorms
 While flying in nimbostratus cloud, the pilot sees a flash of lightning
 What communication, if any, should the pilot make to Air Traffic Services?

options.text: A special observation report because the pilot has encountered an embedded thunderstorm.
The pilot should include the information in the next position report, which is due in 15 minutes.
The observation report can be omitted because thunderstorms were forecast.
A PAN call on the frequency in use because the pilot`s message is urgent.

variant.question: What should you add, if you are flying an aircraft with a mass of more than 136 000 kg?

options.text: The suffix HEAVY shall be added after your call sign.
Add HUGE after your call sign.
There is no particular word to say since the controller already knows the type of your aircraft.
The suffix SUPER shall be added after your call sign.

variant.question: Which of the following weather phenomena should be reported to ATC?

options.text: Embedded cumulonimbus (CB).
Sandstorm, well left of your track.
Light turbulence.
Streaks of altostratus (AS) clouds ahead of you.

variant.question: Isolated CBs have been forecast along the planned route. When flying in a layer of nimbostratus clouds, the pilots see a lightning flash. What actions should they take?

options.text: Transmit a Special-Air-Report because the CB is embedded.
Report the lightning flash at the next waypoint, which is only 15 minutes away.
Declare a PAN PAN as the aircraft has flown into a storm.
CBs have been forecast, no further action needed.

variant.question: Air traffic may require routine met reports of air temp, wind, speed, icing or any turbulence. aircraft without data link are ?

options.text: exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required to by ATC
Must inform atc they have no data link capabilities
Need to make the reports via ACARS instead
May request to divert if severe weather is expected ahead

variant.question: When are you exempted from making meteorological reports?

options.text: When your aircraft is ADS-C equipped unless ATC requests you.
When you did not log-on to CPDLC.
In case of adverse weather.
Never.

variant.question: An aircraft is at cruising level when severe turbulence affects its capability to maintain the height-keeping requirements for RVSM. The pilot should inform ATC by transmitting...

options.text: 'Unable RVSM due to turbulence'
'Negative RVSM'
'RVSM not approved due turbulence'
'Not RVSM any more due to turbulence'

variant.question: You are Pilot-In-Command of a scheduled international commercial air transport flight, flying at FL140. Your aircraft is equipped with all the necessary communication and navigation equipment. After 30 minutes of flight at cruising altitude, you notice the unserviceability of the air-ground data link. Weather conditions at the moment are moderate to severe icing. What is correct regarding the meteorological observation?

options.text: Because the data link is unserviceable, a special meteorological observation should be transmitted via voice communications.
The routine meteorological observations that are normally transmitted every 15 minutes should now be sent via voice communications.
You should attempt to re-start the data link system so that routine meteorological observations can be sent. If this remains unserviceable, a special transponder code should be selected.
Because the data link is unserviceable, you are exempted from transmitting both routine and special meteorological observations.

variant.question: Given the following METAR select the correct statement:21010KT 2200 SCT015CB BKN025 QNH1020 BLSN

options.text: Visibility 2200m, QNH1020, blowing snow.
Visibility 2200m, QNH1020, patches light snow.
Wind in direction 210 at 10 kts, visibility 2200m, QNH1020
Cloud 5 to 7 oktas CB's at 1500ft, QNH 1020

variant.question: When the term Overcast is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what is the amount of clouds covering the sky?

options.text: It means poor ground visibility.
50% or more.
Less than 50%.

variant.question:
You are concerned about the cloud ceiling at your destination 300 nm away.
Where can you get the latest weather information?

options.text: VOLMET
Listen to the aerodrome ATIS
Use your TAF from 5 hours ago.
Call FIS and ask if the TAF has been amended.

variant.question: How is the visibility in an aviation routine weather report (METAR) expressed in plain language?

options.text: up to 5 000 m in metres, above in kilometres.
in feet and nautical miles.
in nautical miles only.
up to 1 500 m in metres, above in kilometres.

variant.question: How is the visibility in an aviation routine weather report (METAR) expressed in plain language?

options.text: Up to 5000 m in metres, above in kilometres.
In nautical miles only.
In feet and nautical miles.
Up to 1500 m in metres, above in kilometres.

variant.question: The latest MET REPORT for UUDY states: UUDY **291200Z** **14006G11MPS** **0600** **R14/1400U** FG SCT010 OVC020 03/M04 **Q1003**. The pilot of an aircraft approaching UUDY asks ATC for the latest RVR. Based on the current METAR, what is the controller’s response?

options.text: RVR runway one-four 1 400 meter upward tendency.
RVR runway one-four 1 400 meter downward tendency.
RVR runway one-four 1 400 meter will rise during the next 2 hours.
RVR runway one-four 1 400 meter unchanged.

variant.question: When the term "BROKEN" is used in aviation routine weather report (METAR), the amount of clouds covering the sky is:

options.text: 5 to 7 oktas.
8 oktas below 10 000 feet.
1 to 4 oktas.
No clouds below 5 000 feet.

variant.question: Consider the following METAR:LFPG 150505Z 27015KT 9999 SCT016 OVC024 M09/M12 Q1006 NOSIG. Which option is correct?

options.text: The wind is westerly at 15 kt, the temperature is 9° Celsius below zero, and the QNH is 7 hPa less than ISA (International Standard Atmosphere).
Visibility is greater than 10 km, the cloud base is at 2400 ft, and the temperature is 6° Celsius less than ISA (International Standard Atmosphere).
The time of the report is 05:05 UTC, the temperature is 9° Celsius, and the weather is expected to remain the same.
The time of the report is 15:05 UTC, there are scattered clouds at 1600 ft AMSL, and the dew point is 9° Fahrenheit.

variant.question: How can aviation routine weather reports (METAR) of specific airports be obtained by aircraft in flight?

options.text: VOLMET
ATIS
SIGMET
AFIS

variant.question: Which of the following statements regarding a METAR is correct:

options.text: Wind direction is given in degrees true.
Visibility given is the minimum visibility observed on the horizon.
Only CB clouds are reported.
METAR observations are carried out every 20 minutes.

variant.question: Which statement is true concerning a METAR?

options.text: Wind direction is reported in degrees true.
Wind direction is reported relative to grid north and speed is reported in km/h.
Wind direction is reported in degrees magnetic.
Wind direction is reported relative to magnetic north and speed is reported in km/h.

variant.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced. During climb an aircraft with data link communication equipment are:

options.text: Expected to report every 30 seconds during the climb-out phase for the first 10 minutes of the flight.
Required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
Obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft’s position.
Exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required by ATC.

variant.question: The pilots of an aircraft are approaching their destination and report severe turbulence between FL100 and FL070. This report will be classified as...

options.text: a special aircraft observation.
a routine aircraft observation.
a pilot aftercast observation.
a non-routine aircraft observation.

variant.question: When the term 'Scattered' is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what is the amount of cloud covering the sky?

options.text: Half or less than half of the sky is covered(3 or 4 octas).
The sky is entirely covered (8 octas).
More than half but less than the full sky is covered(5 to 7 octas).
The sky is clear below 5000 feet/GND.

variant.question: When the term 'Broken' is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what is the amount of cloud covering the sky?

options.text: 5 to 7 octas.
1 to 4 octas.
8 octas below 10000 feet.
Clear sky below 5000 feet.

variant.question: When the term 'Overcast' is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what is the amount of clouds covering the sky?

options.text: It means poor ground visibility.
50% or more.
Less than 50%.

The pilot of an aircraft approaching UUDY asks ATC for the latest RVR. Based on the current METAR, what is the controller’s response?

options.text: RVR runway one four 1400 meter upward tendency

variant.question: An aircraft is 500 NM from its destination and the pilot is concerned about possible low cloud formation affecting the approach. How should he/she be able to obtain the most accurate forecast now, for an arrival in about one hour?

options.text: Get the D-ATIS through datalink by the onboard ACARS.
Ask the flight information service to check if the TAF has been amended.
Relay on TAF issued 5 hour’s ago for the aerodrome.
Transmit on the VOLMET broadcast on an SHF frequency.

variant.question: An aircraft is 300 NM from its destination and the pilot is concerned about possible low cloud formation affecting the approach. How should he/she be able to obtain the most accurate forecast now, for an arrival in one hour?

options.text: Listen to the report transmitted on the VOLMET broadcast.
Relay on TAF issued 5 hour’s ago for the aerodrome.
Ask the flight information service to check if the TAF has been amended.
Call on the aerodrome ATIS frequency to request a forecast on hand.

variant.question: An aircraft is 300 NM from its destination and the pilot is concerned about possible low cloud formation affecting the approach. How should he/she be able to obtain the most accurate forecast now, for an arrival in one hour?

options.text: Listen to the report transmitted on the VOLMET broadcast.
Relay on TAF issued 5 hour's ago for the aerodrome.
Ask the flight information service to check if the TAF has been amended.
Call on the aerodrome ATIS frequency to request a forecast on hand.

options.text: Maintain listening watch on the VOLMET frequency.

no significant cloud.

variant.question: Who is responsible for the issuance of special air-reports?

options.text: The pilots.

variant.question: Under which of the following circumstances shall an aircraft station squawk 7600?

options.text: In case of radio communication failure.
When entering bad weather areas.
When flying over desert areas.
When approaching a prohibited area.

variant.question: An aircraft is 300 NM from its destination. The pilot is concerned about possible low cloud affecting the approach. How should he/she be able to obtain the most accurate forecast now, for an arrival in one hour’s time?

options.text: Listen to the reports transmitted on the VOLMET broadcast.
Rely on the TAF issued 5 hours ago for the aerodrome.

variant.question: During a flight you encounter a thunderstorm which is embedded in other clouds. You:

options.text: report it as soon as possible, by reporting it as a special air-report.
do not need to report it.
should report it together with your next scheduled routine metrological report.
report this information after landing at your destination.

variant.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced.Aircraft without data link communication equipment are..

options.text: exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required by ATC.
expected to report only once, immediately after the request.
required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft’s position.

variant.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced. Aircraft without data link communication equipment are...

required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
expected to report only once, immediately after the request.
obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft's position.

options.text: A heavy sandstorm in the vicinity but not on the track.
Light icing.
An isolated thunderstorm affecting the track.
Any turbulence.

variant.question: The route forecast included the chance of isolated thunderstorms. While flying in nimbostratus clouds, the pilot sees a flash of lightning. What communication, if any, should the pilot make to ATS?

options.text: A special observation report should be made because the pilot has encountered an embedded thunderstorm.
A PAN call on the frequency in use should be made because the pilots' message is urgent.
The observation report can be omitted because thunderstorms were forecast.
The pilot should include the information in the next position report, which is due in 15 min.

variant.question: Which of the following observations should be reported to ATC?

options.text: Volcanic eruption seen in the distance
Light icing
Isolated Cb along the route
Patches of fog along the route

variant.question: Which of the following weather conditions would need to be reported to ATC.

options.text: Major dust storm some distance from track.
Isolated thunderstorm close to track.
Light turbulence on track.
Light icing.

variant.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, in the aircraft`s next routine meteorological report.
There is no requirement to report such a thunderstorm.
Yes, after landing.

variant.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, after landing.

variant.question: An aircraft in flight encounters an isolated thunderstorm that is obscured by other cloud. The aircraft does not encounter hail. Must this be reported, and if so, when?

options.text: Yes, as soon as possible in a special report.
Yes, in the aircraft's next routine meteorological report.
Yes, after landing.

variant.question: When would a METAR cause an immediate update to an ATIS?

options.text: Upon receipt of a METAR SPECI
Upon receipt of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values.
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a reportable value.
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR ; otherwise hourly.

Light icing.
Isolated CB's that have not been forecast.

variant.question: While an aircraft is in cruise, the pilots encounter an isolated thunderstorm obscured behind a cloud. There is no hail. The pilots should...

options.text: Submit a special air report.
Not do anything, because only embedded thunderstorms require a special report.
Make a PAN call on their active frequency as this is an urgent message; other aircraft are possibly threatened by the thunderstorm.
Report the encounter in the next routine meteorological report.
